unnormalised: Someone asked me about the correct way to write Indian addresses for sending letters and parcels, especially to make sure they arrive without delay. It’s a good question because there are some important details that can make a big difference.
normalised: Someone asked me about the correct way to write Indian addresses for sending letters and parcels, especially to make sure they arrive without delay. It is a good question because there are some important details that can make a big difference.

unnormalised: First off, always start with the most specific info: the house number and building name, if any. For example, "H.No. 123, Shanti Niketan Apartments" is a good start. Then, write the street name or locality. Let's say it’s "MG Road" or "Sector 15". After that, include the city and district. So it could be something like "Gurgaon, Haryana".
normalised: First off, always start with the most specific info: the house number and building name, if any. For example, "H dot N-O dot one hundred and twenty three, Shanti Niketan Apartments" is a good start. Then, write the street name or locality. Let us say it is "M-G Road" or "Sector fifteen". After that, include the city and district. So it could be something like "Gurgaon, Haryana".

unnormalised: The most important part, that many people overlook, is the PIN code. This is a 6-digit number, like "110001" for areas in Delhi, and it’s crucial for sorting and delivery. Make sure it's accurate! Include the state name as well, even if it seems redundant. It helps in cases where city names are duplicated across states. For example, you might have "Siliguri, West Bengal, 734001".
normalised: The most important part, that many people overlook, is the P-I-N code. This is a six-digit number, like "one hundred and ten thousand and one" for areas in Delhi, and it is crucial for sorting and delivery. Make sure it is accurate! Include the state name as well, even if it seems redundant. It helps in cases where city names are duplicated across states. For example, you might have "Siliguri, West Bengal, seven hundred and thirty four thousand and one".

unnormalised: So, putting it all together, a complete address would look something like this: "Priya Sharma, H. No. 456, Green Valley, Sector 22, Chandigarh, 160022, Punjab". Make sure everything is clear and legible, especially the PIN code. This helps ensure your letters and packages reach their destination quickly and reliably. Also, for international shipments to India, remember to include "India" at the very end of the address.
